docs.lead_paragraph: A handful of bonds backed by yearly payments from tobacco companies under a landmark settlement with 46 states are in the earliest stages of default, and more distress is expected.

headline.seo: State Bonds Backed by Tobacco Payments in Jeopardy of Default
headline.main: State Bonds in Jeopardy as Tobacco Cash Fades
headline.print_headline: State Bonds In Jeopardy As Tobacco Cash Fades

docs.abstract: Steady declines in smoking are creating problems for municipal bond investors; handful of bonds backed by yearly payments from tobacco companies under a landmark settlement in 1998 with 46 states are in the earliest stages of default, and more distress is expected; there are roughly $55 billion in outstanding tobacco bonds.
docs.snippet: A handful of bonds backed by yearly payments from tobacco companies under a landmark settlement with 46 states are in the earliest stages of default, and more distress is expected.

docs.lead_paragraph: Noteworthy cultural events taking place in New York.
docs.snippet: Noteworthy cultural events taking place in New York.

docs.lead_paragraph: Louise M. Slaughter, a 13-term New York Democrat, can only watch from a wheelchair as her Republican opponent meets voters and raises funds.

headline.seo: Congresswoman Slaughter Bent on Pursuing Election, Broken Leg and All
headline.main: Broken Leg Adds Hurdle to Her Quest, at 82, for 14th House Term
headline.print_headline: Broken Leg Adds Hurdle to Her Quest, at 82, for 14th House Term

docs.abstract: Rep Louise M Slaughter is the oldest woman in Congress at age 82 and has represented Rochester, NY, for a quarter century; she is seeking re-election but, because of an accident, can only watch from a wheelchair as her Republican opponent, Maggie A Brooks, meets voters and raises funds; redistricting has left her with a new, more conservative constituency that is less favorable to Democrats than her previous district.
docs.snippet: Louise M. Slaughter, a 13-term New York Democrat, can only watch from a wheelchair as her Republican opponent meets voters and raises funds.

docs.lead_paragraph: Bryan Huffman, a close friend of the heiress Rachel Mellon, says he thought the donations Ms. Mellon made to John Edwards were strictly to help him become president.

headline.seo: Rachel Mellon’s Friend Testifies About Donations to Edwards
headline.main: Go-Between for Heiress Details Link to Edwards
headline.print_headline: Go-Between For Heiress Details Link To Edwards

docs.abstract: Bryan Huffman, close friend of elderly heiress Rachel Mellon, takes the stand in the federal trial of John Edwards; Huffman details how he funneled nearly $750,000 from Mellon to Edwards aide Andrew Young, who in turn used the funds to cover up the candidate's extramarital affair.
docs.snippet: Bryan Huffman, a close friend of the heiress Rachel Mellon, says he thought the donations Ms. Mellon made to John Edwards were strictly to help him become president.

byline.original: By WILLIAM DUPRE and KIM SEVERSON

docs.lead_paragraph: Nearly 20 years ago, a multimillion-dollar ad campaign created a fictional couple - ''Harry and Louise'' - to dramatize the dangers of President Bill Clinton's health care reforms. Now, President Obama is trying to use the same Madison Avenue-style technique to demonstrate how his policies would be better for women than would Mitt Romney's.

headline.main: From 'Harry and Louise' To Obama's 'Julia' Ad

docs.abstract: Caucus column; Obama campaign creates fictional woman named 'Julia,' and uses her life story to demonstrate how the president's policies would be better for women than those of Mitt Romney. (M)
docs.snippet: Nearly 20 years ago, a multimillion-dollar ad campaign created a fictional couple - ''Harry and Louise'' - to dramatize the dangers of President Bill Clinton's health care reforms.     Now, President Obama is trying to use the same Madison...

headline.main: For Republicans, Clear Approach to Medicare Has Many Sides

docs.abstract: Among Republican fiscal hawks, the 2012 election is supposed to be a stark choice between a Republican Party willing to make tough spending decisions and a Democratic Party relying on "Mediscare" tactics to avoid responsibility.
docs.snippet: Among Republican fiscal hawks, the 2012 election is supposed to be a stark choice between a Republican Party willing to make tough spending decisions and a Democratic Party relying on "Mediscare" tactics to avoid responsibility.

headline.print_headline: From ‘Harry and Louise’ To Obama’s ‘Julia’ Ad

docs.abstract: A hypothetical girl goes through life as a poster child for President Obama's policies as the campaign for women's votes continues.
docs.snippet: A hypothetical girl goes through life as a poster child for President Obama's policies as the campaign for women's votes continues.

headline.main: Many Parents Are Financially Supporting Adult Children After College, Study Finds

docs.abstract: Most baby boomers have allowed their adult children to move back home after college graduation, rent free, according to a new study.
docs.snippet: Most baby boomers have allowed their adult children to move back home after college graduation, rent free, according to a new study.

headline.main: Most Baby Boomers Help Pay Their Adult Children's Expenses

docs.abstract: Most baby boomers say they help their adult children cover expenses.
docs.snippet: Most baby boomers say they help their adult children cover expenses.

headline.main: Mitt Romney and Paul Ryan's Budget

docs.abstract: Mr. Romney seems to be embracing proposals that would push Medicare costs onto consumers and help big banks.
